channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only
channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Scientific Panel Says Editing Heritable Human Genes Could Be OK In The Future
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The National Academy of Medicine and National Academy of Sciences say a long-standing taboo on editing human genes could be lifted — even if the changes can be carried through to future generations.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The National Academy of Medicine and National Academy of Sciences say a long-standing taboo on editing human genes could be lifted — even if the changes can be carried through to future generations. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/14/514580162/scientific-panel-says-editing-heritable-human-genes-could-be-ok-in-the-future

item.title: Iron Age Potters Carefully Recorded Earth's Magnetic Field — By Accident
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The planet's magnetic field is weakening. Scientists aren't sure why, but studying ancient jars could help them find out. The ceramics provide a remarkable window onto Earth's magnetic past.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The planet's magnetic field is weakening. Scientists aren't sure why, but studying ancient jars could help them find out. The ceramics provide a remarkable window onto Earth's magnetic past. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/14/515032512/iron-age-potters-carefully-recorded-earths-magnetic-field-by-accident

item.title: From Vector To Zoonotic: A Glossary For Infectious Diseases
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The world of infectious diseases has more than a few words and phrases you might want to know more about. We've got definitions for 11 key terms.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The world of infectious diseases has more than a few words and phrases you might want to know more about. We've got definitions for 11 key terms. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/14/512875686/from-vector-to-zoonotic-a-glossary-for-infectious-diseases

item.title: Why Killer Viruses Are On The Rise
item.description: February 14, 2017 - If you think there are more dangerous infectious diseases than ever, you're right. One big reason: pushing animals like this one out of their homes.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - If you think there are more dangerous infectious diseases than ever, you're right. One big reason: pushing animals like this one out of their homes. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/14/511227050/why-killer-viruses-are-on-the-rise

item.title: Hookup Culture: The Unspoken Rules of Sex on College Campuses
item.description: February 14, 2017 - Research suggests that college students are not having more sex than their parents were a generation ago. But sociologist Lisa Wade says the culture around sex has changed dramatically.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - Research suggests that college students are not having more sex than their parents were a generation ago. But sociologist Lisa Wade says the culture around sex has changed dramatically. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/14/514578429/hookup-culture-the-unspoken-rules-of-sex-on-college-campuses

item.title: 90 Percent Of Fish We Use For Fishmeal Could Be Used To Feed Humans Instead
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Currently, one-fourth of all fish caught globally goes to produce fishmeal and fish oil for farmed seafood, pigs and chickens. A lot of it is "food grade" and could be feeding the world's hungry.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Currently, one-fourth of all fish caught globally goes to produce fishmeal and fish oil for farmed seafood, pigs and chickens. A lot of it is "food grade" and could be feeding the world's hungry. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/13/515057834/90-percent-of-fish-we-use-for-fishmeal-could-be-used-to-feed-humans-instead

item.title: Pollution Has Worked Its Way Down To The World's Deepest Waters
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Tiny creatures in the Mariana Trench have high levels of industrial contamination. The new findings suggest that even Earth's most remote locales feel the effects of human beings.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Tiny creatures in the Mariana Trench have high levels of industrial contamination. The new findings suggest that even Earth's most remote locales feel the effects of human beings. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/13/514997248/pollution-has-worked-its-way-down-to-the-worlds-deepest-waters

item.title: A Brain Tweak Lets Mice Abstain From Cocaine
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Scientists have created addiction-resistant mice by altering the reward system in their brains. The findings shed light on the biochemistry of addiction.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Scientists have created addiction-resistant mice by altering the reward system in their brains. The findings shed light on the biochemistry of addiction. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/13/514590646/a-brain-tweak-lets-mice-abstain-from-cocaine

item.title: To Save The Planet, Give Cows Better Pasture
item.description: February 13, 2017 - What's the single most important thing that the world's farmers could do to reduce global warming? Give cattle — especially in the tropics — faster-growing, more nutritious pasture.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - What's the single most important thing that the world's farmers could do to reduce global warming? Give cattle — especially in the tropics — faster-growing, more nutritious pasture. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/13/514070632/to-save-the-planet-give-cows-better-pasture

item.title: Signs Of Hope At Oroville Dam, After Overflow Sparked Large Evacuation Sunday
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Lake Oroville's water level has finally dropped below its record high, after residents scrambled to comply with an evacuation order Sunday.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Lake Oroville's water level has finally dropped below its record high, after residents scrambled to comply with an evacuation order Sunday. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/13/514955209/signs-of-hope-at-oroville-dam-after-water-overflowed-emergency-spillway

item.title: This Heatless Habanero Packs All Of The Flavor With None Of The Burn
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Some breeders vie to grow ever more mouth-burning peppers. The guy behind the Habanada had a different goal: a habanero with no heat all. The aromatic, melon-like result is winning over top chefs.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Some breeders vie to grow ever more mouth-burning peppers. The guy behind the Habanada had a different goal: a habanero with no heat all. The aromatic, melon-like result is winning over top chefs. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/13/514106139/this-heatless-habanero-packs-all-of-the-flavor-with-none-of-the-burn

item.title: Depression Strikes Today's Teen Girls Especially Hard
item.description: February 13, 2017 - A study tracking depression rates among U.S. teens from 2005 to 2014 finds an increase — especially among girls. A steady diet of harsh judgments from social media may play a role, researchers say.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - A study tracking depression rates among U.S. teens from 2005 to 2014 finds an increase — especially among girls. A steady diet of harsh judgments from social media may play a role, researchers say. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/13/514353285/depression-strikes-todays-teen-girls-especially-hard

item.title: Remembering The 'Edutainer' Who Made Statistics Come To Life
item.description: February 11, 2017 - He called himself an "edutainer." His gift was bringing statistics about the world to life. Stanford mathematician Keith Devlin remembers Swedish statistician Hans Rosling, who died this week.
item.itunes:summary: February 11, 2017 - He called himself an "edutainer." His gift was bringing statistics about the world to life. Stanford mathematician Keith Devlin remembers Swedish statistician Hans Rosling, who died this week. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/11/514650904/remembering-the-edutainer-who-made-statistics-come-to-life

item.title: Saving The Planet, One Burger At A Time: This Juicy Patty Is Meat-Free
item.description: February 11, 2017 - Pat Brown was a renowned biomedical researcher. But he left that to tackle what he saw as the biggest problem facing Earth: animal agriculture. His solution: a veggie burger so beef-like it bleeds.
item.itunes:summary: February 11, 2017 - Pat Brown was a renowned biomedical researcher. But he left that to tackle what he saw as the biggest problem facing Earth: animal agriculture. His solution: a veggie burger so beef-like it bleeds. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/11/514544431/saving-the-planet-one-burger-at-a-time-this-juicy-patty-is-meat-free

item.title: Look Up! Astronomer Details Upcoming Trifecta Of Celestial Activity
item.description: February 10, 2017 - First, go outside, then look up! There's a trifecta of celestial activity Friday night, says astronomer Jackie Faherty, plus another sky watching tip.
item.itunes:summary: February 10, 2017 - First, go outside, then look up! There's a trifecta of celestial activity Friday night, says astronomer Jackie Faherty, plus another sky watching tip. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/10/514566981/look-up-astronomer-details-upcoming-trifecta-of-celestial-activity
